definitions.title: Frankness
definitions.definition: Frankness means being open, honest, and direct in speech or expression.
definitions.example: Example: He spoke with frankness about the team‚Äôs weaknesses.
definitions.explanation: When someone shows frankness, they communicate truthfully without hiding their real thoughts or feelings.

definitions.title: Postscript (P.S.)
definitions.definition: A postscript is a short message added at the end of a letter after the main body has been completed.
definitions.example: Example: P.S. Don‚Äôt forget to bring your umbrella tomorrow!
definitions.explanation: A postscript allows the writer to include an extra thought or reminder after signing off.

definitions.title: Infatuated
definitions.definition: Infatuated means having an intense but short-lived passion or admiration for someone.
definitions.example: Example: He was infatuated with her beauty and charm.
definitions.explanation: Infatuation often involves strong romantic feelings that are emotional rather than logical.

definitions.title: Lace
definitions.definition: Lace is a delicate fabric made of fine threads with open patterns of holes.
definitions.example: Example: The bride‚Äôs dress was adorned with white lace.
definitions.explanation: Lace is often used for decoration in clothing and accessories because of its elegant and intricate design.

definitions.title: Sphinx
definitions.definition: The Sphinx is a mythical creature with the body of a lion and the head of a human, found in Egypt and Greek mythology.
definitions.example: Example: The Great Sphinx of Giza is one of Egypt‚Äôs most famous monuments.
definitions.explanation: In mythology, the Sphinx symbolizes mystery, strength, and wisdom, often posing riddles to travelers.

definitions.title: Oedipus and the Sphinx
definitions.definition: A Greek myth in which the hero Oedipus answers the Sphinx‚Äôs riddle and frees Thebes from her curse.
definitions.example: Example: Oedipus solved the Sphinx‚Äôs riddle by answering 'Man.'
definitions.explanation: This myth highlights human intelligence and destiny ‚Äî central themes in Greek mythology.

definitions.title: Compare
definitions.definition: To compare means to examine two or more things to find their similarities.
definitions.example: Example: When you compare cats and dogs, both are common household pets.
definitions.explanation: Comparison helps identify what makes things alike or related in purpose, feature, or meaning.

definitions.title: Contrast
definitions.definition: To contrast means to examine two or more things to find their differences.
definitions.example: Example: When you contrast day and night, one is bright while the other is dark.
definitions.explanation: Contrasting allows readers to see distinctions or opposing qualities between concepts.

definitions.title: Protagonist
definitions.definition: The protagonist is the main character in a story who faces the main conflict.
definitions.example: Example: Harry Potter is the protagonist in the Harry Potter series.
definitions.explanation: The protagonist drives the plot and often undergoes personal growth throughout the story.

definitions.title: Antagonist
definitions.definition: The antagonist is the character who opposes the main character or creates conflict.
definitions.example: Example: Voldemort is the antagonist in the Harry Potter series.
definitions.explanation: The antagonist‚Äôs actions challenge the protagonist and create the central tension in the story.
